results.title: The Painter's world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present
results.brief_description: A six-part series which explores how and why paintings are made. Each program traces the development of a given subject from the Renaisance to the present, showing how artists can act both conventionally within or radically against constants, always responding to existing works and conditions.
results.title_for_label: The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present

results.title: The Painter
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Art of silence: pantomimes with Marcel Marceau and his partner Pierre Verry”.
Mime makes the invisible visible and the visible invisible. Marceau’s sometimes comical - but always graceful - interpretation of The Painter in Central Park allows the viewer to “see” objects which are not there.

results.title: The Painted men
results.brief_description: Filmed in and around Hanuabada village, Port Moresby, this story of the abduction of a native girl by ”painted men” and her rescue by her lover was made for the entertainment of local audiences. It is claimed to be the first Papua New Guinean film with an indigenous cast.
results.description: Filmed in and around Hanuabada village, Port Moresby, this story of the abduction of a native girl by ”painted men” and her rescue by her lover was made for the entertainment of local audiences. It is claimed to be the first Papua New Guinean film with an indigenous cast.

results.title: The Pack of women
results.creator_credit: Diana Manson, ABC-TV (Australia) and Ted Robinson
results.brief_description: The pack of women was first devised by Robyn Archer as a cabaret for the stage, and as such it played in London in 1981 and toured Australia in 1983/84. It involved three women and three musicians playing, speaking, dancing and singing - in turns serious, tender, witty, angry, outrageous, sombre, hilarious. All the songs, poetry and prose fitted together to make up a mosaic of new ways of looking at women. Old images were juxtaposed with new lyrics, layers of irony and humour bringing out startling new meanings in familiar songs, and new songs celebrating new women. This version is designed to be as enriching in terms of visual wit and density as it is in text, persuasion and performance.

results.title: The Pacific century. Study guide
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Pacific century”.
To accompany The Pacific century telecourse. The purpose of The Study guide is to aid students in their study of the telecourse material. Included are: an overview, identification of study resources, study focus statements, a listing of key concepts and names, a glossary, time-frame questions, questions for review and additional recommended readings.

results.title: The Pacific century
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
Final part of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten continues his discussion on the Asian economic miracle questioning the popular belief that the new millenium will belong to the Pacific Rim. He briefly talks about Thailand, from the days of its feudal society to its now modern industrial state which is facing an economic crisis following a crash in the “building boom” of the 1990s. More in depth coverage however, is given to Singapore and Japan - historical, economical and political - pointing out the differences in culture and traditions of both nations and the reasons behind their successes and failures in the world of economics. He points out Singapore’s reliance on its efficient, well educated and willing workforce who forego their individual rights and freedoms for the common good of the State and Japan’s tradition of loyalty to the company and a “job for life” being put under pressure as the younger generation demand freedom and choice in their careers and workplace culture. The program contains several interviews with various leaders and company personnel including the former Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kwan Yew, along with Chris Patten’s personal commentary and opinions. The series is well presented, informative and interesting from a socio-economic point of view - Chris Patten provides the human touch. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Spencer, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: The Pacific century
results.creator_credit: Al Levin, Marc Levin, Teleac Holland, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Pacific century”.
The final program in the series looks at America’s future as a “Pacific nation” by charting current economic and political trends, including the flood of Asian investment in the U.S., the domination of Asian technology and the rapid growth of Asian immigration. Through portraits of politicians, business leaders and working men and women “The Pacific century” will confront the economic, political and cultural challenges that will determine America’s future in this region to which it is inextricably connected.
